results.title: Central perspectives (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Art Landy and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Reviews the definition of range and pencil. Introduces the basic projective transformation, namely the central perspectivity. When the narrator poses the question of the number of points required to uniquely determine a projectivity (product of perspectivity) the viewer is led to the fundamental theorem of projective geometry.

results.title: Geokids
results.creator_credit: Hank Saroyan, Caroline Somers, Bruce Somers Jnr and Lost Kitty Productions
results.brief_description: Created by Han Saroyan of the “Muppet babies”, this series features three amazingly life-like animal characters called Sunny, Bobby and Balzac. Small children are able to learn about many different types of animals and the way they behave.

results.title: Waves and beaches
results.creator_credit: Eric Harrison, Julia Spark and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Geography today: a search for order”.
Examines the relationship between waves and beaches on Spurn head on the north shore of the Humber Estuary. Simulated demonstrations, using time-lapse photography, show the effects of waves and sand in a wave tank. Discusses sediment movement and the effect of different amounts of wave energy on beaches. Simple field experiments examine the factors effecting the size and shape of a beach. Suitable for senior students due to technical language and complex concepts.

results.title: Aspects of Central Place
results.creator_credit: Eric Harrison, Julia Spark and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geography today: a search for order”.
This film uses the Cambridge area of the United Kingdom to discuss the applicability of Christaller’s central place theory in a modern context. Explains the forces that have given growth to the city of Cambridge and the functions of centres at different levels of the settlement hierarchy in Canmbridge. Suitable for Upper-Secondary students.

results.title: The West Indies
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geography of the Americas”.
Discusses the varied population, terrain, resources and opportunities for economic growth of the West Indies, modern trends toward industry, and traditions of large plantations and small farms raising a large variety of semi-tropical crops.

results.title: Mexico
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geography of the Americas”.
Explains that Mexico is divided into three main regions - northern plateau, central plateau and coastal lowlands. Describes various occupations and crops of these areas, showing how they have been affected by the geography of the country. Shows the home life of a corn farmner who lives on the Central Plateau. Includes scenes of Torreon, Monterey, Zacatecas, Mexico City and Veracruz.

results.title: Central America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geography of the Americas”.
Describes the three main topographical regions of Central America - hot lowlands, temperate plateau, and cool mountain lands. Shows effects of climate on inhabitants and crops. Shows how coffee is grown and shipped. Discusses the economic importance of the Panama Canal.

results.title: Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geography of the Americas”.
This film discusses the cities, industries, agriculture and natural resources of each of the major geographical divisions of Canada. While the film looks at the western region, the central prairies, the Great Lakes region, the Maritime Provinces and the Yukon, it also points out similarities between Canada and the United States.
